Nuestro reportero habló con decenas de jóvenes para explorar la naturaleza cambiante de la adolescencia en Estados Unidos. Al preguntarles cuál es la fuente principal de sus dificultades de salud mental, notó que se repetía una palabra: “soledad”. https://t.co/DNxzq3oTQH https://t.co/HVZRBhZCoF

La crisis de salud mental en los jóvenes de EE. UU. se intensificó con la pandemia. Según varios hospitales y médicos, es una emergencia nacional que atraviesa grupos étnicos y raciales, áreas urbanas y rurales, sin importar el nivel socioeconómico. https://t.co/DNxzq3oTQH https://t.co/t2kK8QFp9O

En EE. UU., las visitas a las salas de emergencias de niños y adolescentes motivadas por ansiedad y autolesiones aumentaron en 2019. Las tasas de suicidio, estables de 2000 a 2007, aumentaron casi 60% en 2018 en los chicos de 10 a 24 años, según los CDC. https://t.co/DNxzq3oTQH https://t.co/vZHEc6ew5i

Los adolescentes en EE. UU. sufren un cambio drástico. Hace tres décadas, los riesgos a la salud de estos jóvenes se debían a la bebida, el embarazo y el tabaco. Estas causas han disminuido mientraslas tasas de trastornos de salud mental se han disparado. https://t.co/DNxzq3oTQH

The war in Ukraine has laid bare the ethical tensions in surrogacy arrangements, casting into bold relief the power dynamics of a contract in which a woman signs over the whole of her physical self. Read @susandominus’s cover story in @NYTMag:
https://t.co/v24c8vUpSt https://t.co/pErjwrdzLd

There was a logistical problem to moving a group of 13 pregnant women: surrogacy was not legal or straightforward in many countries near Ukraine. If any of them went into labor and delivered there, the surrogate would be considered the child’s mother.  https://t.co/v24c8vCgEl

Some of the intended parents were pressing for the families of their surrogate to be moved to safety, and were frustrated by why it hadn’t happened sooner; Some surrogates felt their children were in less danger if they stayed where they were than if they took to the road. https://t.co/n9R6nWEMKn
It had been hard enough to persuade the women to go to Lviv. Now that the war was on, many were reluctant to abandon their country and travel even farther from their families. https://t.co/v24c8vCgEl

In February, once Russia invaded Ukraine, many of the intended parents were insistent to make sure that their surrogates leave Ukraine altogether — to leave Lviv and go to Poland, for the surrogates’ safety and the safety of the children they carried. 
https://t.co/v24c8vCgEl

Many of the other surrogates considered this trip an unnecessary disruption — no one in Ukraine really expected full-scale war. But the agency told them they needed to pack all their legal documents and come to the train station the evening of Feb. 15. 
https://t.co/v24c8vCgEl https://t.co/lENaxAkJ40
Maryna and Nataliia were both surrogates in Kyiv, two of 13 pregnant women working with an American company. That agency, as of mid-February, decided to move everyone to Lviv. https://t.co/v24c8vCgEl

Now, Ukraine’s surrogates are working under the worst of circumstances, forcing everyone involved — agencies, intended parents and surrogates — to make decisions based on imperfect information regarding matters of life and death.
https://t.co/v24c8vCgEl

In some, but not all, cases, the parents choose to build a relationship with the woman carrying their child. Even under the best of circumstances, the arrangement can be fraught. https://t.co/v24c8vCgEl

@susandominus Typically, parents who opt for surrogacy fly in work with a local clinic, conceiving embryos that are subsequently implanted in the wombs of Ukrainian women whom they have interviewed (usually by video call) or chosen from descriptions the agency provides. https://t.co/v24c8vCgEl https://t.co/ZrJt3aAdna

@susandominus Since various countries have restricted international surrogacy, agencies have rushed in to take advantage of Ukraine’s relatively well-regulated surrogacy industry. 
https://t.co/v24c8vCgEl https://t.co/q9Z6fYmPeb

In small settings, Koch occasionally shared disarming fragments with gay friends. One said Koch came out to him at a private dinner around 1985, opening the meal with a question: "Do your parents know that you’re gay?"
They do, the friend said.
"Too late for me," Koch replied.

Koch was a cautious gay rights ally and the first mayor to march in New York's Pride parade. But when AIDS hit, some advisers said he had to proceed carefully with what they called a "gay issue." As the "Tucker Carlson Tonight" playbook sent sponsors fleeing, Fox filled the space with in-house promos. 

Last May, after promoting the white supremacist "replacement" theory, Carlson had half as many advertisers as in December 2018 but brought in almost twice as much money.

Journalists on Fox's daytime shows discerned a pattern to what the audience didn't like, including segments featuring Fox's own reporters and stories deemed unfavorable to Trump. Immigration, on the other hand, was a hit. Coverage of migrant caravans became a Fox mainstay.

Fox looked to the success of "Tucker Carlson Tonight" as a model for its own transformation. 

According to former executives and employees, Carlson's on-air provocations have long been part of a data-driven experiment that has succeeded in bolstering the Fox profit machine.

Carlson put Trumpism over Trump. 

Donald Trump had a symbiotic relationship with Fox, and Carlson wanted to reach the Trump base without being beholden to the president. Carlson's show would grasp the core of Trump's allure while keeping a measured distance from the president.

For years, Carlson has amplified talking points from the far-right fringe.

Last spring, Carlson caused an uproar when he promoted the notion of the "great replacement" — a racist conspiracy theory that he's amplified in more than 400 episodes, our analysis found.

Tucker Carlson weaponized his viewers' fears to create what may be the most racist show in the history of cable news. 

Our examination shows how intertwined his rise has been with the transformation of Fox News and U.S. conservatism. Some takeaways: https://t.co/esT86zvAqZ

The earliest plastics weren’t meant to be disposable. In the early 1900s, they were a more sustainable replacement for natural resources, like tortoise shells, ivory, and animal horns. 

So how did single-use plastics become such a problem? Read more.
https://t.co/wWEtVLoVzV

Producing the plastic itself creates planet-warming greenhouse gases and other pollutants. In 2015, plastics created 4.5% of global greenhouse gas emissions, one recent study estimated, or more than all the world’s airplanes combined. 
https://t.co/wWEtVLoVzV https://t.co/i3rhfmut7G

Plastic hangs around for centuries once discarded, breaking into ever smaller particles that spread and can carry toxins.

These microplastics have been found in drinking water, table salt, Antarctic ice, rainfall and, recently, in human blood.
https://t.co/wWEtVLoVzV

The world produces plastic at an explosive rate.

The weight of all plastic ever made is now greater than all land and marine animals combined. And half of items are made to be used once, the UN said — hotel shampoo mini-bottles, single-use flossing picks, at-home Covid tests. https://t.co/ZbVOIyBWOv

Most recyclable items are never recycled.

An estimated 9% of all plastics ever manufactured have been recycled, the UN Environment Program said, and nearly 80% ended up in landfills, dumps or in the natural environment — the rest ends up being burned. 
https://t.co/wWEtVLoVzV https://t.co/On8X9SnZxC

12/ There are multiple paths the story of the peatlands could take. We welcome you to reflect on the latest story from Headway and tell us what do you think will happen next? https://t.co/kWkmDFC8Q5

11/ The mere discovery of these peatlands has upset fragile relationships among communities and raises significant questions about how to protect this vast carbon sink, who pays the price and what those protectors might get in return.
https://t.co/kWkmDFC8Q5

10/ This is Papy Ekate Ekofo, the minister of environment for Équateur Province, in Kinshasa, where he was trying to get government funds to rein in illegal logging.

“The way they are logging is murder. If they continue to log like this, the peatlands will be destroyed.” https://t.co/tBI8XHxs5T

10/ Seated is Jean-Paul Ikolongo Sefala Yekay, the chief of the village of Mpeka. Many of the places where peat has been found in the Congo, like Mpeka, are reachable only by boat.

He is frustrated that the village hasn't benefited when the researchers take peat samples. https://t.co/XdkzdFasC3

9/ This is Yomi Bonyele, a hunter from Lokolama. Fishing and hunting pose little threat to the peat. It is logging companies and large-scale development that researchers fear.
https://t.co/kWkmDFC8Q5 https://t.co/3pGztmtV1d

8/ Meet Joseph Lombo Bokanga, known as Tout Va Bien. He lives in Penzele, a village next to Lokolama.

“If we cut down the trees, the peatlands will let go of their carbon and it will destroy the world. So if we don’t cut them down, what can we expect from the world in return?” https://t.co/O79o1tiQEz

7/ This is Mimi Mboyo Boleko. She’s fishing in the peatlands. Until recently, people from Lokolama frequently went to the peatlands to fish, hunt and collect mushrooms. Not now. Not since they had been told to protect them.
https://t.co/kWkmDFC8Q5 https://t.co/r9rDDYeAtF

6/ Here’s Ovide Emba, the student of peat from Mbandaka, a riverside city of decaying Belgian colonial buildings and a million people.

Emba dreads the future for his beloved peatlands. “If the state does nothing, in 50 years’ time,” he said, “I don’t even want to imagine.” https://t.co/5vBBvqnavX

5/ This is Therèse Bokinga. She’s standing on the road in Lokolama after mushroom hunting. She’s the “village mom” of Ovide Emba, a university student researching the peatlands in Lokolama.
https://t.co/kWkmDFC8Q5 https://t.co/gkKhpC8PgM

4/ This is Joseph Bonkile Engobo, known to all as Papa Joseph. He’s a traditional chief of Lokolama, a village in Congo, and home to a few dozen families deep in the equatorial forest

“We are the guardians of the forest,” Papa Joseph said. https://t.co/kWkmDFC8Q5 https://t.co/f9h2Wwtoxk

3/ The international community wants to preserve the peatlands and protect them from loggers and other outside forces. But who is asked to do that?

Here are some of the people living in and around this ecosystem quietly saving the planet.

Portraits were shot by @HeitmannNanna.

2/ The biggest network of tropical peatlands in the world runs through Congo. They store more than 30 billion tons of carbon. And they're under threat.

If all were destroyed, the carbon equivalent of 20 years of US fossil fuel emissions would be released into the atmosphere.

1/ Outsiders have long exploited the wealth of natural resources — rubber, diamonds, gold and, more recently, cobalt — in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

Peatlands can take on many forms, from bogs and fens to deeper cuts: pocosins, palsa, blanket bogs and tropical peat swamp forests. https://t.co/FFC8WBBTQr https://t.co/7ofJKTEwja
Although peatlands make up a tiny percentage of land on Earth, they store twice as much carbon as all the world’s forests combined. https://t.co/FFC8WBBTQr https://t.co/4A9PXRavgd

But the thick brown muck holds a secret: loads of carbon sealed underground and away from the atmosphere, making peat one of the world’s best carbon sinks. https://t.co/FFC8WBBTQr https://t.co/fFEpMnyF00

In grounds too soggy for dead things to decompose, plants pile up in layer after layer, forming thick, muddy peat. https://t.co/FFC8WBBTQr https://t.co/sSO8zp1QYL

Next, the books head to a machine called the backer, which readies them for the cardboard cover to be attached, then to a case-in machine to apply the casing, then to a jacket wrapper machine that wraps the book with the printed and cut book jackets. https://t.co/V4X8TFS4LI https://t.co/2k8OBCBQB2

Next is the binding:

At a bindery, printed pages are loaded into a gathering machine. That machine will put the pages together in order, arranging them as a complete piece for the first time. Then, each book is trimmed and glued together. https://t.co/V4X8TFS4LI https://t.co/T8bR9YXI1H

At the end of the printing press, the 32-page sections are automatically cut and folded. The printed sections are then bundled together to keep them in place until they are bound. https://t.co/V4X8TFS4LI https://t.co/O3q8lHyw8F

On printing day, plates of text are installed. Giant rolls of paper, about 800 pounds each, are spliced and spooled. The book is printed 32 pages at a time, and every few hours, the plates must be swapped out so the next 32 pages can be printed. https://t.co/V4X8TFS4LI https://t.co/5guCxDHAAR

Next is the press:

“Moon Witch, Spider King” was printed by Lakeside Book Company, one of the largest printing companies in the U.S. The facility where it was printed runs 24 hours a day, seven days a week; it turns out millions of books each week. https://t.co/V4X8TFS4LI https://t.co/Oovto5AKsN

Proofs of the cover are made to inspect the colors, and then the print run begins. After the covers are printed and laminated, they are put on a truck and driven to a plant that will print the book and package them all together. https://t.co/V4X8TFS4LI https://t.co/93eG8mmsOY

The book jacket is printed first: 

The cover for “Moon Witch, Spider King” is unusually complicated. Most covers are printed using black, cyan, magenta and yellow ink, but two additional colors were used for this one: Day-Glo green and a special blue. https://t.co/V4X8TFS4LI https://t.co/HQE492Aneh
